novel_text:
Before the first light smudged the edges of the coast, Alec was already out among the sheep with a thermos of cheap coffee and a fleece he’d pulled from the nail in the tack room. Fog lay in folds over the mid-slope, as if the hills had thrown blankets up to their chins and were pretending to sleep. He rubbed his hands together, breath pluming, and listened to the invisible Pacific pounding somewhere beyond the eucalyptus and the pale rise of grass. The smell of salt drifted inland on a slow wind, furled with the ammoniacal sweetness of the flock and the mineral damp of dew. He spoke softly into it all, to the dog, to the wary ewes and lambs, to himself.

"Easy," he said, though nothing was happening. "We got time."

He’d never thought he’d end up shepherding. That was a story for people with a family tract and a bible of irrigations, not a boy who’d left San Luis at nineteen to forget one thing after another. Yet here he was, on a leased patch outside Cayucos, where grass grew brittle in summer and washed back into luminous green by January, and where the year buckled itself around the tides and the market price per head. He had a decent eye for sick animals and a better hand with fences. The rest he’d learned by listening to old men at the auction yard, by making mistakes and then quietly doing something harder the morning after.

The dog’s name was Madrone, a rust-bellied mix with a solemn intelligence, and she ghosted at his heel until he sent her wide. "Keep ’em tight, Mo." She swung like a hinge, and the sheep drew together with the reluctance of sleepy schoolchildren.

When the sun finally nudged up, it cut through the fog and made it luminous, layers of milk and gold. The fence line along the eastern boundary ran down toward a dry arroyo and then back up toward his house, a low-slung barn swallow of a building that had once been a shack for pickers. Before he’d leased, a realtor had shown him listings with ocean views and banked decks, all the predictable glass. He’d said no, feeling strange even as he said it. He wanted this: the smell of dirt that had been turned over, a roof that could peel back shingle by shingle until he relearned weather.

Below the house, an acre or so of ground lay stubborn and matted with fennel and bristly ox-tongue, a piece he’d promised himself he’d fix "next week" for three months. He imagined rows of brassicas, a little pocket of kitchen herbs, whatever didn’t roll over and die when the north wind got personal. But his hands always ended up with hay twine in them instead of seeds. He had an agreement with the landowner to tend the old apple trees along the driveway too, which had suffered from someone’s bright idea to let the grass grow tall around them. He’d meant to learn about pruning angles and was instead learning how to drink coffee at one in the morning without noticing it.

He finished the pass along the low pasture and stood with his palm on the fence post, feeling the vibration of Madrone’s body as the dog pressed against him for praise. The road was still except for a single pickup moving slow as a prayer, and beyond it the ocean, a flat bruise.

By eight the fog had climbed to a high ceiling and turned thin. He was in the lower garden with a borrowed spade, cutting along the border to see if he could coax it into a shape that didn’t look like a crime scene. His phone buzzed in his pocket and he ignored it, thinking it might be a feed delivery, or his vet, or someone selling something. It stopped. Started again. Stopped.

A voice carried down the drive, unexpectedly close. "You Alec?"

He looked up, blinking, and the woman on the other side of the fence raised her hat in lieu of a handshake. She had the kind of hat people wore in old pictures: straw, frayed, a blood-orange ribbon threaded through the crown. Her hair was tucked under it, but a wing of it had come loose at her temple. Her jeans were scuffed, her shirt was printed with lemons that had faded to ghost-citrus. She was not young-but-old, or old-but-young; she had that look people who’ve worked outside get, as if the air had carved them a little.

"I am," he said, pushing the spade into the soil with the side of his boot. "Can I help you?"

"Maybe," she said. "I’m Marin."

"Like the county?"

"Like the sea." She rested her forearms on the top rail, making the boards creak. The air around her smelled like wet rosemary and wood smoke, and he realized she’d carried it with her, not the morning carrying it for her. "I heard you were looking. For someone to smack your weeds around. A gardener." She said the last word in a different tone, half teasing, as if it were something you bought at a roadside stand.

He wiped his hand on his jeans and offered it, and she took it without flinching. "I am," he admitted. "Or I was, and then I started to believe maybe the weeds were winning and that this was their land anyway."

"They do that," she said. "It makes them happy, you know, the lying down in mass graves." She pointed with her chin at the fennel and the burrs and the scutch grass that had thrummed up overnight, or so it seemed. "This is honest soil. It just wants you to understand what it’s capable of."

That made him smile, despite himself. "How’d you hear?"

"Maya, at South Bay Nurseries. I worked there a while, through winter. She said you were the shepherd with a soft spot for apples and a sore back."

"Maya," he said, with an involuntary fondness. She’d given him two ragged flats of kale like a blessing and told him the secret to avocados was not to try to raise them in an argument with the wind. "I do have a sore back."

"Let me walk it," Marin said. "I don’t do chemicals. I get mad at Roundup like it did something to me personally. I do hand weeding, sheet mulching, tricks, conversation, sometimes music if the dirt wants it. I like being paid in cash, we can be grown-ups about it. I work Wednesdays elsewhere and I’m at the harbor on Fridays, so Mondays and Thursdays for you if you like me. I have references. I saw your apples, by the way; the short answer is, those need a day and a ladder and someone unafraid of metaphor. The long answer is, oh boy."

"The harbor," he said. "You sail?"

"Sometimes." She shrugged. "I like looking at lines. I help with a little boat that needs always fixing. Don’t look at me like that. It’s almost; it’s almost not stupid."

"I was thinking of the ocean," he said, though he’d been thinking of her mouth when she said almost, the way certain words tilted the corners of her lips. He was not a man who studied mouths.

"Well, that too. It’s big. Sometimes it’s blue. I’m Marin, like I said. You are… what did Maya say… Alec-of-the-hills."

"She did not say that," he said, alarmed.

"She did," Marin reported, delighted. "In her inside voice. Listen. Pay me sixty-five an hour. Pay me seventy when it’s trees because I don’t like arguing with ladders. I’ll bring a truck and tools, because yours look like they have feelings and I don’t want to hurt them."

"You didn’t ask me if I was going to hire you."

"That would be assuming no," she said. "And I don’t like living in futures that don’t want me." Then her face went a little softer, the joke taking its coat off. "I need work, and I like land that’s been looked at honestly. You didn’t put in fake lawn. You didn’t call it a lawn ironically and then it turns out to be fake-corn in spring and fake-snow in winter. You put fence up yourself; see how this nail bends. You care. So I want to work here. I want to get dirt under my nails and say hello to the dog and not get yelled at for drinking water on the job."

"Pay at the end of the day," he said, as if he were laying a board on firm supports. "Cash is fine. I should probably look at references. Not because. You know. But because."

She nodded. "Write this number down. There’s a woman named Esperanza, over in Los Osos. I took a yard of oxalis and made it cry, she’ll tell you. There’s also a guy named Wyatt who thinks I’m a witch. He’ll tell you that too. It’s because I talk to his squash."

"I talk to my sheep," he said. "We’ll get along."

She cut him a look then, one of those starboard-tilting looks, amused and measuring, and then she took her hat off and wiped her forehead with the back of her wrist. Her hair came down a little. It was brown, and in it there was a streak of something like iron, or a mistake.

"Can you start now?" he asked. He heard himself, the eagerness in it, and immediately wanted the ground to take him down a rung.

"I can," she said. "Give me an hour, though. I left a trowel in my van and the van in Morro Bay, which is a long story involving a bird and a piece of toast." She tipped the hat back on. "Tomorrow then? Seven? It’s cooler. And I get to watch your dog take himself seriously."

He agreed to seven. After she’d gone, the place felt like it had inhaled and then held it, waiting.

He spent the afternoon cutting thistle by the arroyo and hauled out three stumps he’d promised the landowner he’d deal with before last month’s rent. He ate a sandwich over the sink, watching the ceiling fan stutter. The phone buzzed again. He looked: Evelyn. He swung his thumb over the accept button and then he didn’t. He set the phone down, picked it up, took his breath like a drink and hit call.

"You finally alive?" she said. He could hear her smile, the old one, the one she had used to soften everything from a traffic ticket to a too-brutal truth.

"Been alive all day," he said. "How are you, Evie."

"You don't call me that," she said. It was automatic. Not unkind. They were in the tender place after a divorce where labels were suddenly knives handed to children. "Sorry. You can. I have a thing I need. If you’re willing."

"What kind of thing."

"Paperwork," she said. "Dried hell. The registration for the Subaru, because you’re still listed, and the DMV is what it is. If you could sign something without bleeding, I would be grateful. I can come up. I know the dog will roll over and pretend he’s never met me, but I’ll bring something stinky."

"I’m here," he said. "Tomorrow morning."

"At…?"

"Seven," he said, and then he flinched. "Seven-thirty? Eight? I’ll be around. Early is okay."

"Alec," she said quietly, and he was suddenly terrified of what she might say next. But she went somewhere else. "You’re eating?"

"Yes."

"You’re not making Max eat beans out of a can."

"Max is a dog," he said. It was stupid, and they both laughed a little, the way once in a while the body laughs to show the heart what walking could be like. "Come when you like. There’ll be coffee. The cheap stuff."

"We drink cheap coffee now?"

"I drink it at all hours," he said. "The sheep don’t care."

"Sheep never did care," she agreed, and then they fell silent in a way that was kind of a blessing. "See you," she said, and hung up before either of them could do anything wrong.

That night, he lay awake on the couch, not because his bed was uncomfortable, but because the couch faced the window and the window was a rectangle of black that held in it the idea of the sea. Sometimes, late, he turned off every light and walked out to the fence line and listened to the whales when they came through, hearing them as rumors the water told the air. You could pick out something exquisite from the emptiness if you stood still long enough. He did not do that tonight. He stared at the shadow shapes until they softened and brightened, until dawn came and the dog nosed his knee and said in her useless, beautiful way, hey.

He had the kettle on when Marin’s van pulled in, a white beater with a dangling mirror and a new tire. She jumped out as if she had been thrown by something glad. Madrone went to meet her as if they’d been planning this reunion for weeks. In five minutes Marin had set up her tools along the fence: a fork, a long hoe, a coil of drip line like a sleeping snake, a bundle of cardboard cut into sheets.

"Today we’re going to make your weeds think twice," she announced, rubbing her palms together as if she were about to install a heart in a whale. "We’re going to feed your soil. We’re going to inflate your sense of possibility. Shall we."

He watched her work. You could learn a person by the way they moved one thing to make space for another. She knelt and pushed her hand under the mat of grass like someone reaching under a bed. She lifted it like a rug, laughing breathlessly when it gave, and the smell that came up was dark and mushroomy. She layered cardboard, soaked it, laid wood chips, adjusted the hose as if it were a living thing with preferences. She hummed under her breath. Not a song he recognized. Something made of three notes and a path between them.

"You should plant broad beans here," she said, pointing with her elbow. "Let them do your heavy lifting. Let them flirt with the earth."

"Is that a phrase you can use," he asked, "with beans."

"If I can talk to someone’s squash, yes."

At eight-thirty, Evelyn’s car came up the driveway, and Marin stood, shading her eyes, and Alec felt, in the slop of his chest, something like childhood panic. The old life meeting the new. The two parts of himself who did not share language except in the way bodies face each other, reluctantly, with honor.

Evelyn got out with a manila folder and nothing else. She had cut her hair short since he’d last seen her, and it made her neck look like something out of a painting. She wore a knitted sweater the color of over-steeped tea, and it made her skin look like something a person might take care of. She held herself in check until she saw Madrone, and then she crouched and the dog washed her hands with her tongue and whirled against her, thudding, whining in that way dogs have that sounds like a complaint and is not.

"Hello," she said, looking up at him, not getting up yet. "You look like you’ve been eating. Which is good."

"You look like someone who goes inside to make a phone call," he said, which was something she used to say to him when he had tested the limits of network coverage more than the limits of patience. He bent down too, rubbed the dog’s neck, his hand bumping into hers and then not. "This is Marin. She’s—" He hesitated, aware of the oddness of the introduction. Boss? Worker? Another word, older than both of those, not appropriate in the place they were.

"Gardening," Marin supplied, standing and dusting her knees. "I mean, staring at dirt and telling it stories until it agrees to still be dirt."

"Ah," Evelyn said, straightening. "I’m Ev—. I’m Evelyn. Hi. This place… looks. It looks good. It really does." She was careful, and he was grateful. She handed him the folder. "Sign where the tabs are. I brought each page because last time we guessed wrong."

He took the papers into the kitchen because the wind at the edge of the day was busy with them and they could turn the world into confetti in a minute. Evelyn followed, and Marin stayed out with the dog, bending a hose around her forearm like a lasso.

"Do you want coffee?" he asked.

"I’m a little jittery," she said. "I had a dentist appointment and then I didn’t go. Because I’m a child. Sorry. You don’t need to hear that." She leaned against the counter. "I heard you lost a ewe last week. Maya told me. Sorry. Is that appropriate? I’m sorry about you losing a sheep. This is not a greeting I ever imagined practicing, but here we are."

"It happens," he said, and the words were stones that fell cleanly without making a new dent in the earth. "You learn to respect weakness without letting it run the show. You learn to watch."

"Yes," she said. "I am trying to learn."

He signaled the line with a finger, and she heard the old language in it and handed him a pen without looking. He signed twice. She said thank you in a tone that was almost nothing, but that had in it a small room with a chair. A place to rest.

"Who’s the gardener?" she asked, after a minute. "She’s…"

"She’s Marin. She knows everything about dirt. She has opinions about beans. She talks to squash. She works at the harbor on Fridays."

"The harbor."

"Don’t start," he said, unexpectedly flushed. "I don’t mean. She’s a person. I hired a person."

"Of course," Evelyn said, her face perfect. "You should. Hire as many people as you need. You’ve always needed a crew. You think you’re a lone cowboy because you watched movies on Saturday afternoons and then went for drives without telling anyone where you were going, but you need people. Just—" She stopped. Something like pain crossed her face, very fast, like a shadow of a fast bird. "Just be careful with your heart, okay? It’s made of the same stuff as everyone else’s. Despite your theories."

"Hypothesis," he said, because he was a fool. "It was a hypothesis."

She laughed despite herself, and the laugh did something to his insides that was both good and terrible. "Sign the back too," she said. And then, more gently: "She’ll be good for the place. It looks, already. I don’t know. Different. Like the land knows you’re watching."

"You always say things like that."

"I happen to believe we are observed. By the things we own or think we own. And by the things we can’t see." She held the pen for a second longer than was necessary before sliding it into her sweater pocket. "Do you need anything? Money? No? You’ll tell me, right?"

"Of course," he lied, and then didn’t.

They went back outside. Marin had built a low wall of mulch and cardboard like an altar. She showed him the way to tuck the edges in. She showed him how the soil felt when you stopped fighting it. Evelyn stood by, her hands in her pockets, watching with the careful, deliberate interest of someone who had left and was still allowed to be here. It was awkward as rain on a wedding day. It was also exactly the right weather for what was happening.

"I should go," Evelyn said, when Marin stood and stretched and the dog flopped under the apple tree and became a long yellow line. "It’s a long drive and I forgot breakfast."

"Do you want a peach?" Marin asked. "I have a peach. It’s not good. It’s a little mealy. It’s honest about it, though. You can have it anyway."

"I have this thing about peaches," Evelyn said, smiling. "They taste like promises. I break promises with my teeth. Thank you but no."

"Suit yourself," Marin said, and took a bite that left her with juice on her chin. She wiped it with the back of her hand and looked like a child for exactly a second. She turned to the tree and said, with complete seriousness, "Paper around your trunk. You’ll feel better."

"She talks to trees," Evelyn whispered, as if this required him to be at risk, and Alec felt a surprising anger rise, then pass.

"She listens to them too," he whispered back.

They said goodbye in the driveway in increments. Evelyn put her hand out to shake Marin’s and Marin held it with both of hers like she was reading something through skin.

"If you need help with anything green at your place, I do community rates for ex-wives and nieces and people who have thin dogs," Marin said. "I like making things more livable. It’s my fatal flaw, besides rocks."

"I live in a small apartment with a basil plant that hates me," Evelyn confessed. "If I hire you, it will be to talk to it so it stops singing my failures back to me."

"Ah, basil," Marin said gravely. "The most judgmental herb."

"I knew it," Evelyn said, and they both laughed, and Alec had to put his hands in his pockets to keep himself from reaching out to both of them in different old and new ways. When Evelyn drove away, she rolled down her window and threw him a waiter’s wave, a flick of two fingers off the steering wheel. He took it. He let it stick to him.

He turned back to the yard. Marin had peeled off her flannel and tied it around her waist. There was a tattoo on her forearm he hadn’t noticed: a small boat, almost a child’s drawing, nothing dramatic—but it had ropes and a little mast and a black edge to its hull like a promise. The word under it was almost unreadable. He squinted. Not a name. Two words.

She caught him looking. "It’s fine," she said. "People can look. It’s only a story I wrote once and then had to put somewhere."

"What does it say."

"It says ‘stay small’."

"People always tell you to dream big."

"They do," she said, bending to fix the hose. "And it breaks too many hands."

They worked until the sun was high and the fog had burned off and the sheep had moved into an area that had nothing left to recommend it. At noon he made sandwiches and they ate sitting on the low back step with their feet in the dirt. Without intending to, he asked her what brought her to the harbor.

"A boat," she said, through bread. "A ketch with a soft deck and a loud engine that’s in love with the attention it needs. Some of us are fixing her. Some of us only pretend to. The man who owns her says we’ll see Mexico by winter. The sea says: we’ll see about that." She drank water straight from the hose. "I like working with what keeps trying to kill you. Very polite. Very true. Also I like the way rope feels when you coil it right. The way a knot, a good knot, remembers itself."

"You leave Fridays," he said. "You come back."

"I come back," she said, and then her eyes did something: flickered away and back. "I have some things in storage. I have a plant that needs me to say the names of its hallways. I have debts and a dog I don't have and a hunk of land now that is going to give me a stomach muscle. I have whatever this is. If I leave, I’ll tell you. I won’t let your apples wake up to a stranger."

"I wasn’t asking," he said. He was.

"I know," she said. After a minute: "You were married."

"I was."

"A long time?"

"Long enough to make the hardest mistakes. Not long enough to fix them."

She nodded and ate slowly. She didn’t tell him it would be different with her. She didn’t say anything that made a promise where none could live. She said, "Watch your step," when the dog rolled over into the path like a log.

The afternoon was a soft ache of work. They built an edge to the garden with scavenged bricks and a patience that felt like prayer. Marin taught him how to plant garlic by tucking each clove into the soil as if it were sleeping. She asked him the names of his sheep and he pretended he didn’t name them and then said two anyway: Penny. Star.

"You are too sentimental for ranching," she said, gently.

"I’m a shepherd," he corrected. "Which means sentiment is my only tool besides fences and hope."

At three, a wind came up the canyon that was scented with wildfire even though there wasn’t one, not that day. The summer before, smoke had made everything look like a bad dream. He looked at the hills the way you look at a sleeping baby with a fever. Marin looked too. She put her hand on his forearm without thinking, then took it away as if she’d behaved badly.

"Sorry. I—"

"It’s fine," he said. It was better than fine. It was a hand. It was a thing in the world that said you exist.

She turned away and picked up the fork and went on doing battle with the burdock. He watched her shoulders. He wanted to say something about the sea she liked, and the way it accrued all our leaving. He wanted to tell her about the night he’d driven to Big Sur in a storm and slept in the cab of his truck, listening to rain like a riot on the roof, and how sometimes he still dreamed of that roof failing. He didn’t say any of it. He told her instead to watch out for the sprinkler head over there by the rock. She said thank you. That was enough for then.

By evening, the rough lines of a garden had emerged: beds that logic could walk into, a path that didn’t fight you. He paid her in cash and she counted it once and then tucked it into the front pocket of her jeans without ceremony. She took a plastic bag with some rosemary and a handful of figs. She leaned against the van and tilted her head.

"We did good," she said. "Better than good. The dirt is less angry with us. Your apples are simmering down. And you, shepherd? You look like you slept while your body was awake."

"I feel like I’ve been seen by… something," he said. "An animal I want to know the name of."

"It’s just work," she said, though her eyes were soft. "It’s the only god I got."

She left, and the air seemed to unbutton itself into evening. He poured dry food into Madrone’s bowl and then stood at the sink and ate half a fig straight from the tree, the sweetness intrusive after a day of salt and dirt. The phone buzzed again. He looked. Unknown number. He let it ring out.

Later, after he’d made his one good thing—black beans with garlic and some kind of pepper he’d bought at the market because the man who’d grown it had a story—and after he’d walked the fence line and once more admired the neat edges they’d made, he sat on the porch with a beer and watched the sky lay down and tuck itself in. Stars came late on the coast when the fog stayed, and early when it didn’t. Tonight they came one by one like someone arriving to a party with perfect timing.

He thought of Evelyn’s face, and the way she had watched Marin with an amazement that had nothing to do with jealousy and everything to do with disbelief in her own continued ability to be surprised by other people. He thought of Marin’s tattoo. Stay small. He thought of the sea beyond the ridge and the man who said Mexico by winter. He thought of knots remembering themselves. He had once believed love to be a knot like that. Maybe it was. Maybe you just had to give it slack and time and the right palm to run it through.

He fell asleep in the chair, his head tilted back, mouth open. He woke cold and went inside. He dreamed of fences becoming water and sheep swimming, their eyes like little planets, calm.

In the morning, the cardboard had started to drink the world. He knelt in the damp and pressed his hand flat on it the way you might put a palm to someone’s forehead to check for fever. He felt heat, the heat of decomposition, and it delighted him in a way that felt childish, shameless.

Around eleven, when the air was already a cupped hand of heat, a truck came up the drive too fast. He stood, alarmed, wiping dirt on his thigh. It wasn’t a truck; he corrected himself. It was a boat of a car with a hood big enough to sleep on, the paint oxidized into a lizard skin of red and pale. The driver door opened with a sound, and a man stepped out with grey in his hair and a coat too heavy for the season. He had hands that had spent time on rope. He had the practiced squint of people who measure distances in waves.

"You Alec?" the man asked. It was becoming the refrain of his week.

"I am."

"I’m Owen," the man said. "Friend of Marin. She thought maybe you’d have a second for an old fool with a gasket problem."

Alec blinked. "On the… car?"

"On the boat," the man said, pointing behind him, and only then did Alec see, cresting the hill like a wrong moon, the mast of a ketch strapped to a flatbed. It was ridiculous. It was also somehow right.

"We’re bringing her over to a man with a shop who owes me two favors," Owen said. "She didn’t want to go without saying hello to the land that’s paying for her varnish."

Alec said something like, "Ah," and then found English again. "She can come say hello. I have no varnish but I have water."

Owen grinned, and it made him younger. "That will do. Marin told me you’re the shepherd. That you listen."

"I try."

"Good. Boats need that."

They walked up to the flatbed and the boat, high out of water, seemed both proud and embarrassed, like a ballet dancer at the grocery store in costume. Alec put his hand on the hull without thinking and it was warm as a body. He felt, in his palm, the steady, patient courage of a thing built to move. He understood for a moment something he had never cared to understand about people who go away from shore on purpose.

"She’s leaving in the fall," Owen said, as if this were the part of the conversation Alec had signed up for. "God willing and the creek don’t rise. We’ll need hands. Marina tells me you’ve got strong ones."

"Marin," Alec corrected, because the specificity mattered. "I have sheep."

"So you do," Owen said. "And sometimes the thing you tend tells you who you are. Sometimes it ate your mother, and you keep feeding it anyway. Come down to the harbor Friday. Just to look. You can put your hand on something that has failed and then fixed itself."

Alec said he would, which meant he would go and he would stand with his hands in his pockets and stare at ropes and gulls and the ribs of boats and wonder what possessed him. The boat tilted slightly on the flatbed as if to nod to him. Owen got back in the big car and swung it—gently now—back toward the road. Madrone chased it for exactly ten yards and then sat down as if to say, okay, enough.

He texted Marin after, a message that said: Your boat came up to flirt with my hill. She sent back: She does that. Then: Friday. Come and I’ll buy you a fish taco that will make you change your religion.

He typed: I don’t have a religion. Then he didn’t send it. He put the phone in his pocket and went to move the sheep to the upper pasture, where the grass was taller and the breeze was kinder. The dog moved easy. The sheep did what sheep do, which is to say, they defied prediction while obeying all the laws of sheep.

He went to bed early, sunburned on the nose and forearms. He slept and woke twice in that quick, hard way that feels like drowning though you know it isn’t. He went to the kitchen for water, drank from the tap, and in the black window he saw himself and the small yellow kitchen and the ghost of a boat’s mast like a twig against the sky of his memory. He touched his throat as if he had said something aloud.

In the morning, he met Marin at the gate. She lifted a bag of compost off her shoulder like it was a thing light enough to be reasonable. The dog danced. The sun was in the business of making a day. Somewhere down the hill, he could hear the long horn of a ship turning, sounding its body to other bodies.

"You look like you thought about boats," she said.

"I did."

"Did you think about seasick? Because that’s fair."

"I thought about coiling rope," he said. "And about how knots might help a person tell the truth."

She nodded as if this were not far-fetched. "We tie ourselves on purpose so we don’t fly away in wind. That’s all."

He wanted to tell her he was already tied to a hill, to a dog, to an apple tree with scab he was trying to solve with sudden tenderness. He wanted to say he was not free, and that this made him happy in a way he didn’t know how to trust. Instead he handed her the hose. She picked it up like an instrument, and the water made a music of its own.

The days passed then, the way days do when someone has arrived to stand with you inside them. They built and planted and watered together, and sometimes they didn’t speak for an hour and it didn’t matter. He went with her to the harbor on Friday and watched her climb a ladder to the boat with a fluidity that made him feel he had too many knees. He held lines when asked and tried to love the smell of diesel because she did. He ate a taco and almost changed his mind about god.

Evelyn sent him a picture of the basil plant with a caption that said: still judging. He sent back a picture of a row of beans coming up like punctuation. She wrote: promises. He didn’t argue.

In the third week of Marin working for him, the wind shifted and a fire fifty miles away decided to come their direction, not as flame but as ash. The sky went new. They put masks on and watered things they could not save and then stopped, because water had other jobs. The sheep stood watching with the particular boredom of prey animals who know panic is a currency you cannot spend all at once. Marin’s eyes were flints, lighting without tinder, and he thought, briefly, that there are people made for all the different weather, and he had somehow found one who didn’t laugh at the sky for being itself.

By the time the ash had settled and the news had moved on, a new thing had happened inside his chest. It didn’t have a name. It wasn’t love because love is a word we use for too many things. It was attention, paid without interest, with a kind of ritual. It was watching someone tie her hair up with a hemp string and wanting to be worthy of that string. He was not good at this. He had been married and been bad at this. He was trying to be better by being still and letting his face be readable.

One late afternoon, with the light slanting like someone had tilted the whole world, Marin sat on the fence and swung one boot. "Do you ever think about leaving?" she asked him.

"Leaving what."

"This," she said, gesturing at the hill, the dog, the sheep that looked like rocks until they moved and the rocks that looked like sheep until they didn’t. "The way you live inside of this geography. The loops. The mornings."

"Every day," he said. "And then I think about the first thing the sheep do when I open the gate just right, and it’s a thing that feels like music, and I don’t go."

"I thought you might say that."

"And you," he said. "Do you think about not leaving. At the end of fall."

She didn’t answer for a long time. The silence put down a blanket. "I have a debt," she said finally. "To the boat, to the version of me that keeps getting smaller and is happier for it. There’s something I need to meet out there. If I don’t, I’ll be haunted by my own ankles, the way they itch. But I don’t want to go like a thief. I don’t want to go without planting garlic for someone."

"You’ll tell me," he said. He meant: don’t leave me like a weather change.

"I’ll tell you," she said, and then she slid off the fence and into the work again, and the conversation went away like a tide that had come up to your knees but not higher.

The next morning, Evelyn called and did not bother with the usual mutter of apology that had grown between them like moss. "I’m on my way up," she said. "Don’t panic. I have a thing I need to bring you, and a thing I need to ask you to do if you can."

"You know you can always come," he said, and then wished he could take it back. The invitation was a rope that had to be thrown and then reeled in.

"I crashed my bike last night," she said, with a laugh that wasn’t. "Not like—don’t. I’m okay. But the world spun at a weird speed for a while and my neighbor, Mrs. Patel, freaked out and now I have… alerts. I also have a business card of a neurology clinic that looks like a dentist, and I need you to come with me to be someone who hears things and can say what was said back to me. I know it’s stupid. It’s two o'clock in SLO. Can you. And can I leave the car at your place to remind me you’re real."

"Yes," he said, already lacing boots in his head. "Leave the car, take me. I’ll drive. It’s a deal."

"You don’t need to be kind," she said. "But thank you."

He stood on the porch and waited for her. The fog had called in sick that day, and the sun was already showing its teeth. Marin arrived with a bag of seed and saw Evelyn’s car already there and looked at him with something like a question and something like a resignation that belonged to older people. He wanted to say: I’m not going backward. He wanted to say: I am still, always, the sum of my people. He said: "I have to go to SLO with her. She hit her head."

Marin’s hand came half up between them and then down again. She said, thinly, "Of course. Go. Don’t worry about—"

"I’ll pay you for the day, even if you have to leave."

"I’m not a contractor with a fragile heart," she said, and almost smiled. "I’m a person who can see your hands are shaking. Go be useful. I’ll water the beans and pretend to be you. I’ll talk to the sheep about music, they won’t understand a word."

He laughed despite himself and the fear riding him. He put his hand on her shoulder as he went past, a little unsteady. She leaned in just enough to tell him she had noticed. Then he was in the passenger seat, and then the driver, because Evelyn insisted, and then they were on Highway 1, the ocean to their right blue like rumor, the radio playing nothing the way a good radio sometimes does. She kept touching her temple, and he kept wanting to pull over and hold her head and breathe for her as if he could.

He drove her to the clinic and sat with her in a room that smelled like lemon and old carpet and listened to a doctor with a voice like a kind bell. He wrote things down for her. He didn’t say good when there was nothing good to be said, only probable and careful. He brought her a cup of water and made it seem like he did not need to watch her drink it. He walked her to the restroom and waited outside like a new father, stupid with love and terror that he told himself was only muscle memory. When it was done, when she was allowed to go and call someone tomorrow and sleep on her left side and not take stairs two at a time, he helped her into the car, and she said, out of nowhere, "I’m so angry at my brain for being the thing you touched today."

"Don’t be," he said. "It’s the organ that brought you basil to fight with. It brought you every one of your words."

"It also brought me to you," she said, and then shook her head. "That’s not— I’m not— I know what I’m saying. Don’t panic."

"I’m not," he said, and looked away at a stoplight that was ripening. He was panicking in a slow, organized way, like someone packing a bag for a trip he knew very well.

He took her home, or to what home meant now: a second-floor apartment in a building with a name that tried too hard, a view of a parking lot with a jacaranda in it that had decided to be a celebration despite the car alarms and the teenagers and the heat. He walked her up. He wrote down the phone number of the neighbor. He put a glass of water where she could reach it and made sure the basil plant had its little saucer filled like a tiny, dignified request met.

When he drove back, the light was low and the trees along the creek were practicing being black. He pulled into the driveway and saw that the beans had twined twice around the string Marin had set and that the apple tree had paper at its base like a skirt. He found her behind the shed washing mud off her tools. She looked up, eyebrows askew.

"She okay?" she asked, no ceremony of competitive feeling. Just asking.

"She will be," he said. "I think. I hope."

"Good," said Marin. "Would you like to hear about your garlic? Or do you want to sit and let your heart take its boots off first."

He sat on the step and the dog put her head on his knee. Marin came over and sat near him and did not touch him and did not look at him and stayed in the same space as him until the sound in his chest returned to something he recognized. Then she said, "The garlic is a genius," and they both laughed in the dusk, the way people laugh when they have found, for a minute, a ground that does not wobble.

Night came again, and with it the old noises and new questions. He stood by the window, looking at the place the sea would be if the hill would sit down for a minute and let him see. He thought of the boat and the way the mast had looked like a pencil line against his morning. He thought of Marin’s unarguable leaving, written somewhere already in careful, small script. He thought of Evelyn lying on her couch, one hand on her temple as if holding a roof on.

He did not yet know that everything he loved would align itself along a single day’s axis later that year; that he would be asked to do something that even his stubbornness would call brave; that the way you save one person is sometimes a message delivered to another in a language made entirely of tide. For now he slept, and in the night a fox came and sat at the edge of the garden and watched the cardboard steam in its slow making of soil, its quiet beginning again.The morning after the fox, the garden wore a new grammar. Cardboard had softened as if someone had whispered to it all night, and when Alec pressed his hand to it he felt the sweet heat of undoing traveling into his palm. Madrone found the small prints by the compost and sneezed at them like old gossip. A row of broad beans, which yesterday had been only an idea under wet paper, had pried up their first hooks of green, pale and brave. He walked the fence line as the sun made a pale smear in the east and thought how newly alive the insult of fennel looked when you began to win against it. He could smell the ocean under the usual eucalyptus and sheep and rusted-wire tang of old nails, and for once the smell did not make him want to go anywhere, only to stand with the dog and feel a place claim him like a slow tide.

Marin came with an armful of loppers and a ladder over one shoulder, the whole arrangement casual as laundry. She wore a plain shirt and the lemon one in a bundle, for later, because she said you either ended the day in a flannel or in the sun itself if you were doing trees. The hat was the same; the ribbon looked like a line someone had drawn between summer and fall. They went up the drive where the apples threw long patient shade and Marin leaned her cheek lightly to a tree the way you do with an animal you are about to set a hand on. She talked as she placed the ladder and clipped back the first watersprout, her voice full of practical myth. The tree is an animal pretending to be a fountain, she said. We are here to help it remember which way fruit is supposed to hang. The cuts were small and precise; she showed him the angle with her own forearm, the way a body makes a better tool when it remembers what it’s built to do. He climbed behind her, feet careful on rungs, and she held the ladder with one hand and the story of his foolishness with the other until he did not feel foolish anymore. When a limb fell, fat with bad decisions, Madrone hauled it like a trophy and the two of them laughed because joy was not, strictly speaking, against any regulations.

By midmorning the trees looked less like a rumor and more like intentions. Marin had resin on her wrist that glinted like honey, and when she pulled the kerchief off to wipe her face he saw that the streak in her hair was not iron after all but something more like salt. She charged him the tree rate without blinking, and he handed her two extra bills in a way that tried to say both thank you and do not run your ladder alone on my account. She shrugged the thanks away like a burr and set herself to laying the paper around each trunk as if it were a blessing. He fetched the hose and stood back to watch the water sheet over cardboard and settle into a shimmer before disappearing. The smell that rose was like a remembered promise about rain.

Evelyn texted a picture of a foam helmet and three question marks, and he called her and forced himself to make jokes first and inventory second. She sounded small and frustrated in the way smart people do when their bodies remind them they are mortal. He offered to bring soup and then laughed at himself, because when had he last made soup; she said she had learned to accept mercy without grading it and would take anything except cream of mushroom. Marin listened from the other side of the yard with her head down, the hose making its own valley along the mulch, and when he hung up she looked at him with one of her listening looks, the kind that asks nothing because it wants the answer to arrive from its own desire to be said. He told her the basics because there is a line between basic and betrayal and he was learning to stay on his side of it. Marin nodded and said that the brain is a sassy organ and then asked if basil had been watered, because this was how you cared for someone you had not met in the precise part of their life that was not your business.

Friday at the harbor turned out to be a collage of metal sounds and shadows of gulls and old men in hats that were not jokes. The ketch sat against the pier like a tired queen and Owen stood on the deck with one hand on the shroud and the other gesturing toward a future you could not see if your eyes were too literal. Alec had never been good at ladders that were not touching earth, but he made himself climb because Marin did not ask him to. Up close the boat had a smell he had learned to name from a distance, the conversation between old salt and old oil. A young person with a welded ear cuff and a hammer introduced themself as Hana and handed him a coil of line without apology, as if the world already knew his palms and had a use for them. He held what he was given and watched how rope arced and fell when convinced with a flick of the wrist, admired a knot that sat down in itself and held, and thought of the dozen knots he had learned because sheep will find an exit you never even daydreamed. Owen had the kind of bad-tempered kindness that sailors wear like a ring, and his swearing about the engine was inventive enough to seem like poetry. He showed Alec the shape of the hull from beneath where it was up in a sling and told him the story of a reef off Santa Rosalia as if it were a relative, and Alec realized men become geography when they live with water long enough.

They ate tacos at a picnic table splintered with history, the hot sauce like an argument that ends well. Marin sat facing the water with her heel hooked on the bench in a way that made him feel he’d never quite had a body until someone else sat in one near him. She had smears of something on her forearm that was either blood or paint; she licked a thumb and rubbed at it and it still didn’t go which made her smile. She told him the boat’s name as if she were telling him hers and it didn’t sound foolish, only ordinary and proud. He didn’t ask why stay small lived under a vessel christened to go elsewhere; he could see the logic in contradiction from here. When a boy in a sweatshirt too big came by to sell abalone shells polished by a cousin, Marin bought one for two dollars and said it was for the apples, which made no sense until she tucked it into the fork of a pruned limb later and the whole tree seemed to receive the joke.

The landowner showed up the following week in a car that looked like it had known romance in another decade and now just wanted decency. She was a woman with a braid like a cable and the look of someone for whom shock had been a bad use of time once and so she’d stopped offering it to the world. Ruth, she said, and stood with one boot on a post and looked along the fence line in a way that made him straighten. They walked the orchard and he showed her the places apples had started to shape themselves into confessions. She told him about a cousin sniffing around with a developer’s brochure and how she had told him to go pitch his tents in hell, but a niece had a way of liking glossy paper that made Ruth nervous in the nights when she listened to coyotes make their democratic noise. He felt the lease like a piece of paper in his shirt pocket that wanted a lamination he couldn’t afford. She told him she liked the smell of the place again and that the old man down the hill had asked who’d put their hand on the dirt and finally meant it. He offered her a fig and she took it and ate it half like medicine, half like a memory; when she left she thumped the side of his mailbox as if to make it ring true.

They had their first little emergency two days later and it did not kill anything, which felt like mercy. He found Penny on her side with distension that was too much like a balloon for his heart and he went that quiet that allowed the part of him with competence to put on its coat. He called Madrone to face what needed facing and sent for the trochar and stopped breathing long enough to make the small precise hole that lets ridiculous air become the world again. Marin was there because she had been placing bricks like syllables and when he said hold she held the ewe’s head with a stillness that made her look carved. He did what he had learned from old men and mistakes and the dog had the wisdom to be a statue until it was good to play fool again. The sound the ewe made as she found a new angle against gravity was obscene and decent at once; Marin flinched and then breathed deliberately as if she were coaching her own lungs. Afterward they sat on the grass because sitting is what bodies ask for after you stab an animal out of love, and Marin said that she could do blood but not brains, which made him think of Evelyn and the way mercy takes shapes you don’t choose. He rinsed the tool slow and careful and put it away clean because respect is a habit you build when you expect to need a thing again the next day.

On a Thursday they went to the DMV because there is always one government office and it is everywhere. Evelyn had set an appointment, which was a prayer in that building, and they took a number anyway which made them laugh, the number and the prayer holding hands like bored children. He had never seen his name look so capable of punctuation until it sat in triplicate under fluorescent light. They signed places that had been colored for them because color is how the state gets compassion onto paper. Evelyn wore her hair pulled back with something that might have been meant for one use only and now got two, and she had that look again that made her neck seem like a place someone had painted a sky. They sat with their shoulders not touching and their humor touching everything. When a woman at the counter said “sir” in a way that had almost a lemon tart sweetness to it, he thought about the parts of himself that only came up when strangers asked everything too quickly. Outside, under a palm with the wrong idea about itself, they stood by her Subaru and said goodbye in a good grammar: she touched two fingers to her temple to prove she wasn’t broken, he nodded in a way meant to say both go and stay. Marin drove past going the other direction with the bed of her truck full of straw and honked twice in a rhythm that felt like a secret handshake. Evelyn smiled without turning and said, “Your witch has decent aim,” and he said, “She’s not mine,” and it sounded like all the words people say when they are busy not saying the obvious.

Evenings began to carry a weight he liked, the way bowls of fruit have weight when someone is coming over. Sometimes he and Marin ate together on the back step and sometimes he took his sandwich to the fence and pretended he had opinions a fence could use. She did not ask the kinds of questions that require confession for their entertainment; she asked what the wind had been like and he understood that meant she wanted the state of his self, not his secrets. She told him the story under her tattoo one night when the fog had been turned on low like a lamp and the dog had rolled herself into something the temperature could not discover. There had been a time, she said, when she had mistaken big for good and hunger for love; she had set out to become horizon and ended up mostly weather. She had stayed in rooms she should have left because music was playing, and she had left rooms she should have stayed in because music wasn’t. A woman on a boat with hands steadier than God’s had said try small, not as an insult, but as an accurate map, and Marin had taken a pen and written it on the inside of her wrist and then looked up while someone else needled it in. She did not tell him the names of anyone who had handed her either sorrow or salvation, which felt like proof of something you could trust.

He began to learn the currents of the harbor as if they were new paths for the dog. Friday mornings, Madrone watched him leave with a look that was almost complicated; he told himself she was composing an essay about how rope had claimed her person. He brought back to the hill words that did not originally belong to dirt—tabernacle cleat, deadeye, jackline—and put them down among sheet mulch and posts until they sounded like they had always lived there. He found a piece of nautical hardware in his pocket one night, grease black, dense as a threat, and set it on the windowsill like a shrine to all things that hold under strain. The apples started to blush and the garlic put up green that meant business. The beans found their way without asking for help and when he watched them he felt forgiveness for parts of himself he could not shepherd. Marin took a morning off to go to a dentist after months of saying the word like a hex and came back with a new gleam to her smile and three tiny black-and-white pictures of her teeth like moons, which she stuck under a magnet on his fridge for no reason beyond the fact she liked to put proof under cold things.

Ash visited again for two days without the actual insult of flame. The light went to amber and the dog smelled like memory. He filled the stock tank twice and then went inside and did not turn on the news because there are only so many things you can make holy and information isn’t one. Marin worked with a bandanna over her mouth and made jokes with her eyes only, and when she took the cloth down to drink she looked like the photographs of women at strikes he had seen on a calendar once, beautiful in the way that work makes a face plain and plain makes a face truer than hello. Owen showed up with Hana in a truck that did not believe in the concept of mufflers and asked to borrow the hose and left a bag of bolts that could have been coins in a more fortunate kingdom. Hana wandered to the fence with their hands in their pockets and whistled at the sheep in an accent entirely their own, and the ewes pretended not to notice because that is a sheep’s spiritual practice. By afternoon the ash let go like someone who’d remembered a different plan, and he went to the orchard and ran his finger along a leaf and thought of handwriting.

The first time he saw whales that year he did not tell anyone because he wanted a thing that felt like a secret that was all presence and no story. He walked out at midnight wrapped in old flannel and fog and sat on a half-rotted stump and heard the part of the world that holds everything else inhale. The sound came through the hill with a patience that made his own heart feel like an animal that might someday be trained by kindness. In the morning he told Marin anyway, unable not to, and her face changed to the seriousness that certain gifts demand. She said she had been out once on a friend's skiff when a grey had surfaced without any ceremony and looked like real estate, and how after that the idea of faith became less abstract. They stood by the gate and did not plan anything with that in mind; they simply had better reasons, which it turns out is how you leave a day less cruel than you found it.

Wyatt, who thought Marin was a witch, came up the drive one afternoon with the expression of a man whose garden had called him out. He held a zucchini under his arm like a baby he was trying not to admit he adored and asked if witches did house calls for afflicted squash. Marin took his case without offense and sent him home with a lesson on powdery mildew and the suggestion that he name the plant something embarrassing to increase their intimacy. Alec laughed and then wished he hadn’t because Wyatt’s dignity shone like a coin and he admired it. When they were alone again, Marin said that the only people she minded being accused of witchery by were the ones who did it as an excuse to withhold their own responsibility. She flicked a spider the size of a period off her shirt and went back to moving stones as if she’d spoken to a committee.

Summer remembered itself and then forgot and then remembered again. He sold four wethers for a price that made him stand the way a person stands to count what is still in his pockets after a movie with too many explosions. He sat on his kitchen floor and read a pamphlet about drought forgiveness for small agriculture that had been stapled crooked and made dignity miserable by accident. Ruth brought him a clipping about some county board meeting and he promised to go and then didn’t and felt the smallness of that failure like a pebble in his boot and then went the following week instead and sat through two hours of men explaining math to women who had taught it. He spoke once, about fences and hope, and Marin later that night called his voice a tool he’d been hiding behind a paint can, which made him want to buy a shelf for the things he meant to use more.

On a day with winds from the north that tried to make a quarrel of everything, Owen told him there would be a night test run and not to come unless he planned on either staying on land or seeing the inside of his own fragility. He went anyway, of course he did, because fragility is an animal you either meet or it meets you. They pushed off into a harbor that had decided to be a mixing bowl of black glass and breath. The boat moved like a horse that had been taught to wait until you meant it. He held to a rail he trusted and counted the steps between his dignity and his knees. Marin did not coo or encourage; she put his hand where it needed to go and said careful only when careful was an order from physics. Far out, beyond where the pier light made its small human halo, the water’s rules changed in a way he had never asked to learn, and he learned anyway. He did not get sick. He did not become a sailor. He watched Marin grin into wind and thought of debt not as money but as promises you make to parts of yourself that were starving and you fed on purpose. Coming back in, the boat nosed past the working boats with their names like prayers to bills, and he thought not for the first time that he understood why people leave and why they come back and how sometimes it is the same reason wearing two different shirts.

He took Evelyn to her follow-up and they sat in another room with other lemon-scented air and a different doctor who said the same things with slightly rearranged commas. He spent an afternoon fixing her kitchen sink because it dripped in a way that made his shoulder ache by empathy and because he could, and because mercy that takes shape in wrenches is easier to accept at first than the kind that sits and stares at your face until you cry. She told him about a coworker who kept calling her Evie in an awful attempt to be part of the club of her, and he promised to come down to the bookstore and leer while buying three copies of an atlas to make a point. They did not touch except when the wrench slipped and she put her palm against his back to steady him and took it away before anyone could accuse that touch of anything. The basil had finally consented to behave and looked smug, and he told it so, and Evelyn laughed and said look at us, giving names and power to leaves.

September slid down the hills like something forgiving. The apples were light as hands on a face. The beans had made opinions about trellises irrelevant. He woke in the night sometimes with the surety that he had left a gate standing open, and went out in boots and pajamas to count, and found everything where it had promised itself it would be. Marin began to coil her words about leaving into smaller and smaller circles, the way you put rope away when it has earned rest. There was a list on her dashboard with boxes next to it: pharmacy, post office, oil change, Wyatt, Ruth, apples, beans, Owen, harbor gear, shoes, garlic, shepherd. He pretended not to see his name but he saw it and it both wounded and healed him because this is what being seen does if you are honest. She told him she would not go without a blessing from the dog, which seemed both ridiculous and like the only rule that mattered.

On a weeknight that decided to be a weekend early, Ruth hosted a small party that was not a party; people stood in her yard with cups and light on their shoulders and the sound of the ocean doing arithmetic behind the eucalyptus. Someone brought a fiddle that had been taught to make both joy and grief behave and played what it knew, and the old men from the auction yard became younger as they remembered steps they had sworn not to remember. Marin danced a little in place with her eyes closed and then stopped like she had been caught by something she had been trying not to love too much too soon. Evelyn came late, carrying a pie that had clearly argued with her and lost just enough to be perfect, and for an hour Alec stood in a geography of past and future that did not collapse but layered itself like geology. People he had chosen and people who had chosen him and people who had merely tolerated him all mixed until he could not tell which was which and did not need to. Owen told a story about a night off Punta Banda that made someone’s aunt cross herself without remembering she did not do that anymore. Hana taught a kid who had never liked adults to tie a bowline around his own waist and be both caught and free at once. Ruth stood by a fence post and watched everything as if she were keeping weather.

The night after the not-party, the wind died like a toy that had been played with properly. Alec lay on the couch because the couch was where sleep came easiest now and because it faced the rectangle of window where everything that mattered seemed to practice arriving. He thought of all the pieces of rope in his life and the people who had put his hands on them; he thought of his own throat scarred inside by words he had said wrong and the way it still managed to carry water and coffee and breath without needing to let him know how it was doing it. He went to the door and stepped out and the air was clean in the way air is clean when its work for the day has been done and its result is not spectacular but no one has died. On the hill, something moved that was not a sheep and not a dog and not a person and he did not need to name it to know he should not alarm it. The garden breathed as a body breathes when it has learned that change is not always an assault; the cardboard was turning into soil where in a month he would kneel to pull a carrot that had done what no human had asked it to do. In the distance, down beyond what his eyes could hold, a horn sounded across water the way a message moves in a community: not for you alone, but for you too.

He did not know it yet, but by the time the apples were mostly a memory and the garlic heads were hung in braids like old wisdom, the day he had been warned about would walk up the drive as if it was asking for help with a map. He would stand with his palms open and accept and fail and accept again, and the saving would be a physics problem dressed as love. For now there was the smell of rosemary on his hands and the scrape of ladder feet that he had learned to set just so, and the dog sighing into sleep like a tide letting go of its own amazement. For now there was Marin’s van turning into the driveway in the morning, the ribbon on her hat faded almost to a color the sky could only make by accident, and Evelyn’s basil putting up a flower she would be told to pinch back and not and then call repentant over later. The hint of fall arrived the way all honest things do on that coast, by degrees and without an announcement you could put on the calendar. Nights stretched themselves over the shoulders of the hills and stayed there a little longer each morning. The apples took on their last colors with a seriousness that resembled modesty more than show. The harbor started to talk about windows, and how weather lets you out the door sometimes like a mother with her keys already in her hand and sometimes like a bouncer who wants to feel your bones for weapons. Owen’s voice, on the days Alec went down to coil and learn, had a new edge that wasn’t fear so much as arithmetic; he was measuring distances between wishes and facts. Marin began to do that thing with her lists where she stopped pretending they were for someone else to see. She crossed out an item about oil and wrote good rope and drew a box next to Ruth that she shaded in slowly over three separate mornings, as if shading were a way of saying thank you.

The wind shifted from the northwest to a dry chatter out of the inland canyons and every eucalyptus on the hill prepared its flammable gossip. Ruth came up in a truck whose bed had been taught what hay feels like and told him the county had muttered something about shutting the power when the gusts found their business hats. He filled stock tanks as if he were storing quiet. Marin walked the orchard with him and laid her palms against bark like someone speaking into an animal’s better ear; they tucked more paper around the trunks because paper can be a prayer if you give it a job. Owen called from the harbor to say that a man named Shorty with hands like ropes had looked at the engine and said, in a voice like a spoon, that if they didn’t go by the next Friday, they would go a month from now or not at all. “We’re leaving,” Owen said, and it sounded both fine and like a cliff. Marin stood nearby with a coil of drip line over one shoulder and made a face that was almost a smile and then wasn’t, and she didn’t look at Alec because looking is a pressure you don’t put on a thing that’s already got a knot in it.

That night the whales came loud enough that the hill couldn’t pretend not to hear. He went out and sat with his back against the cool of a post and let the sound move his ribs around like furniture. The fox came again and slid along the garden edge like a sentence he would someday be glad to have spoken; it paused by the cardboard that had turned sweet and looked toward the house with the indifference of royalty. Madrone lay down beside him with her head near his knee and sighed in a way that made him think of old men at the auction yard when a good price finally shook out of a stubborn afternoon. He had the thought, not for the first time, that if he stood very still, the land would tell him what it planned to ask. The answer was not words, but he knew it when it came: be ready to be still and to move both, and don’t confuse one for an apology for the other.

The red flag warning went up on a Tuesday, and it was the kind of Tuesday that had forgotten it was not already August. The power snapped off around noon, indecorous, and did not do that coy thing where it comes back on to reassure you and then leaves you again; it meant it. The sky had that thin tin glare that makes everything you own look rude or too bright. Ruth asked if he would mind setting a line of sprinklers along the edge that faced the road because sometimes fire comes to the party you’ve thrown for it, and sometimes it comes through the neighbor’s yard. He minded only the way all people mind water when it has work and they would prefer it to be the kind of friend that just comes by to tell you a joke. He did it anyway. Marin was at the harbor wrapping the last brittle business of departure into duffels and plastic tubs and the kind of old coffee tins everyone thinks they threw away. She sent him a picture of a coil of three-strand laid down good enough to make a priest nod and he wrote back an obedient heart, which looked wrong on the screen until she sent a fish, which made the whole exchange human again.

By midafternoon the north had dropped a handkerchief none of them wanted to pick up. The far ridge put up a column the color of a bruise that had taken a class in theater. Ash traveled the way gossip does when someone is bored and mean. The ewes stood and did their slow calculus about heat and remembered water and the places on their bodies where flies would most like to have opinions. He ran the hose along the fence line and then turned it on his own neck because the body requests cool like it requests truth when it is out of it. Madrone brought the sheep in with that easy authority that made strangers forget how work is built on work and not on the cooperation of fate. Alec was not panicking on the surface; underneath, a patient animal was pacing, and he kept talking to it with words that did not require either of them to be wrong.

His phone buzzed with the old stubbornness of something that wants to be let in. There was a text from Evelyn that began with a name that wasn’t his and ended with his, as if she had been trying on all the beginnings and none fit. The lines were short—dizzy not the cute kind, can you be voice—and then a sentence about the neighbor being gone and a cat who would not leave her shin alone. He felt his chest make that trapdoor motion that ends with your heart on the floor and then climbed down to pick it up and put it back where a heart belongs. He looked at the smoke and then at the flock and then at the dog and then he did the thing he had learned to do since he was nineteen, which is choose and hope choosing isn’t the beginning of the explanation you’ll have to keep offering to no one for years.

He called Marin because he knew the harbor was listening to other music and would be cruel if he asked it to hear his. She answered on the second ring with the sound of something metal arguing with another metal behind her and a voice that was breathless and intent and pointed at someone else until he said her name and then the point turned toward him. He told her the short version, and it was very short because he did not have time to decorate the truth. She said I can go in a way that did not sound like charity, only like the map her day could be folded into without tearing. He gave her the address and the apartment name that tried too hard, and something about a jacaranda tree that had decided to be a parade no matter how many Subarus wore dents beneath it. She said, “I know the building. I know the jacaranda,” and he believed her. He did not say please because he was at the mercy of enough things; she went anyway.

On the hill he cut the fence that was between him and a scrap of Ruth’s lower paddock where the ground went naked and unremarkable, which is exactly what you want when you have animals that wear sweaters in a world full of sparks. He felt the burr of the wire through his gloves and it was a familiar small pain that made him grateful because he knew what to do with it. He whistled the way he whistles when his mouth isn’t interested in being pretty. Madrone moved around the flock like a thought you keep having because it is right. They went through and down, the sound of their feet on dirt like dry beans in a metal bowl, and he closed the opening behind them with a crooked grace that would have made a true carpenter roll his eyes and a true shepherd nod. He used the bowline he had learned from Hana’s hands on a Thursday when the harbor had been in a good mood, and the way it sat in itself did something to his breath. He ran lines from the old oak to the truck and then from the truck to the post because he had become someone who saw rope as both answer and question. When he tied off, he put his palm on the knot the way you touch a shoulder to say we’re not done speaking, but you can rest.

Wyatt arrived with a plastic trash can that had become water for the hour and an expression on his face that announced he had no interest in the narrative but had brought what the narrative required. He said nothing helpful and everything helpful; he said, “Where,” and then he put the water exactly where the hands would be if hands had time to be everywhere at once. Together they moved the last stubborn ewes that had found a reason to be offended by the angle of a shadow. The heat took a breath and then let it out in his face like a dare. The smoke did that thing where it makes a second sky out of the one you will have to miss later. He kept his brain on a short leash in the part of its yard where competence lived and told it to stay inside the fence.

Marin’s van made a noise like a promise going downhill, and she drove it not like a person with somewhere to be but like a person with something to deliver that should not be jostled. In the passenger seat, where a box of bolts or persimmons often rode, sat Evelyn with color in her face that did not belong there. The two women looked like soldiers in a small war that had not made the newspapers yet. Marin had one hand on the wheel and one on Evelyn’s wrist not to measure a pulse but to hand one over if a loan would do any good. They had collected the basil out of superstition, and it sat between them judging everyone as was its right. Marin had said, with the very lightest tone, “I am not your husband and you are not my boss, but I am a person who can say you are not allowed to apologize during the next forty minutes,” and Evelyn had said, with more breath than voice, “You can say that,” and that had been that. They slid into the clinic’s lot and then into a space that someone was kind enough to leave with a hand motion that did not cost them, and the room inside still smelled like lemon and old carpet and authority you could trust.

Back on the hill, it became the kind of midafternoon where time lies down like a dog and kicks its legs because the dream is too much for its body. The fire on the ridge became good television; it made shapes that meant something to the part of the brain that loves a story, and he refused it that comfort because comfort is for later and not for the parts of the day that need you to be accurate. He moved hose and soaked the mulch along the apple trees that had been given their paper skirts, and the steam that came up was like relief learning how to speak. He watered the cardboard because decomposition is a job too, and he would not let it be laid off. Madrone drank and then took a mud bath in exactly the place where he had just put his best work, which is how love makes sure you are still capable of forgiving. Wyatt stayed long enough to make refusing thanks rude, then left because men like him have arranged their lives so they can leave before anyone starts explaining why they came.

He did not check his phone for as long as you can reasonably refuse someone you love, and then he did check, and there were two messages. The first said checked in, and the second said scan okay, short watch, then rest, then soup? The question mark was aggressive and sweet. He realized his whole face had been doing battle with its own muscles and let it give in, which made his mouth feel like a small room you can finally sit down in. He wrote back with one hand while turning a valve with the other, telling her he had black beans and something to pretend at broth and that he had found tortillas that promised a talent they did not possess and made up for it with sincerity. He wrote to Marin a thank you that was unshowy and got back a picture of a vending machine that had refused a dollar three times and then accepted it as if it had been the machine’s idea all along.

By late afternoon the wind’s outline softened and the smoke behaved like a person who has remembered their manners. The power did not come back because power likes to make sure we remember who knows where the switches are. He took the dog to the upper edge of the paddock, and they stood looking at the line where wildland had almost decided to misbehave and then, for reasons none of them could take credit for, had not. He tried to let the part of him that hoards fear empty out through the toes of his boots. Ruth drove by slow and rolled down her window to show her face and the braid like a cable and the look of someone counting the cost of the last two hours in fence posts and invoices and sleep. He lifted a hand and she lifted hers, and they made the smaller kind of agreement that makes the larger kind possible.

The harbor had not been patient, which is not in a harbor’s nature, and the things that could have gone wrong did not, except for one small part of the engine which behaved like an uncle who always tells the story about the time he almost did a brave thing. Owen swore and then made a joke about prayer that would have offended a different God than the one that lived in the business of work. Hana banged their head lightly against a winch and said they were courting wisdom. Marin came back around sunset with salt on her arms as if she had been dipped and set up to cure, and she drove directly to the hill as if there were nothing else a road could do but end where his fence began. She climbed out and leaned on the gate and looked at him with a face that said she had stored facts for him the way refrigerators store mercy. He set a pot on the stove and the flame made its earnest blue, and the beans behaved like beans do when you have told them a story about wanting them to be more than beans.

He did go down to the harbor after he had handed a bowl to a person who could taste appetite again. The sky between the hill and the water chose a peculiar purple that made him think of bruises with opinions. He stood on the pier with his hands in his jacket pockets because jackets were back in fashion by appointment with evening, and Owen pointed at a dozen things and used two dozen words that were new to Alec and three that were not and one that had nothing to do with the topic and was there for love. They cast off for a brief run, not for courage but to remind the boat that it could move without asking permission from the superstition that likes to gather around dry hulls. As they nosed past the end of the breakwater, the ocean made its simple, inscrutable face. He felt the boat underneath him the way you feel another person’s breath when both of you are trying to pretend you’re only sharing a bench, and he smiled because sometimes pretending has the same shape as faith.

There was a horn that night, because there’s always a horn, and it sounded across the fat water like a message sent to anyone who had ears. He thought, stupidly and exactly, of his hill and of the tether he had put on the new gate and of the bowline’s willingness to sit without complaint and be what it had promised. He thought of Evelyn on a couch under a lamp not designed for this, and the way her hand had insisted on being useful even when its person would have forgiven it for not. He thought of Marin’s knuckles with resin stuck in their maps and the word under her boat tattoo that had rearranged the volatility of his days. He touched the rail because touching something keeps your body inside of itself when it is tempted to go flying.

They tied up again without insult or flourish, which is the only way to land if you ask anyone who has landed more than twice. Owen said the window was going to hold and then did the dance all men do when they are trying to predict a person they love who cannot be predicted; he smoked a cigarette that he had already told himself he hadn’t, and then told Alec not to copy him. Hana handed Alec a coil and said, “Show me,” and Alec did, and when the rope lay down like a well-trained dog, Hana said, “Look at you,” in a way that made his ears hot and his hands feel like they belonged on the ends of his arms.

The power came back after midnight with the immodesty of something that gets paid no matter its performance. He woke to the hum like a pot of insects in another room and felt both grateful and amused by the ease with which a house returns to the illusion that it has always had nerves singing under its skin. He found his phone on the counter where it had slept out of courtesy and saw a message from Marin that said soup cured and a message from Evelyn that said basil judge recants and a picture of a plant with its one small flower pinched back and the stubbornness of life still written all over it. He stood at the sink with a glass and watched the water be water and thought about the simple honor of an element doing what it is.

Morning after, the place had put on its clean shirt. The ash had settled into unhelpful corners. The towels on the line looked like flags from a country where everything is domestic and brave in the same hour.
